title: If the universe was infinite, does it mean that there are infinite replicas of everything, even ourselves? - Quora

response.answer_text: What a charming answer to your own question: it is precisely the same one I asked myself in my High School physics class. My answer was to write in my notebook: "There are no infinities or infinitesimals in the Universe". The argument will have occurred to you: since the answer to your question is 'yes', then by reductio-ad-absurdum, the Universe cannot be infinite. Now there is a lot of debate now among my colleagues, especially in cosmology (not my major field), who argue that since the universe is accelerating and there are places in it that we can no longer see or visit because to do so we would have to go faster than lightspeed (visually or physically) and that is not possible (on the modern physics laws that they agree apply). But they have missed your point and mine. To have an infinite universe, we would have to abandon the Big Bang, and allow an infinite past for our universe. These issues are as clear (to me and many if not all) based on fundamental logic plus speed of light and Big Bang origin being the only provisos. We can rely on the universe being finite even if there are now regions in it that we cannot observe or reach. The opponents like to force a distinction between the observable and non-observable parts of the universe, and then say, "The latter is infinite, so you are wrong Dr Muller." That has occurred in these very pages on Quora. Indeed, the questioning of my understanding attracted some amusingly strong and emphatic adjectives! But, given the Big Bang origin, and finite speed of light, THEN I will happily stand on the ground of a finite universe despite the fact that some of it might now be beyond observabilty or no longer within physical reach. We don't actually need the answer, or the reductio. The fact that it started from a localized volume, and has been expanding for only a measurable finite time, it must still be finite. There isn't room in a finite universe for an infinite number of Hydrogen atoms etc. Your question is a very deep one indeed. Thanks for asking it. Keep thinking. You know how to do it!

Don't take this answer too seriously--Dr. Muller's is so much more well-informed, there's no comparison.   But for what it's worth... Consider a nonce-universe that had an infinite volume.     In this make-believe universe, there would be no upper limit on the sizes of  objects.  No matter how many objects our nonce-universe contained, and no matter how big those objects were, there would always be room for a bigger one.    The greater the volume of any given object in this universe, the greater number of features it could have.   I'm assuming that objects in this universe are made of something like atoms and that there is a lower limit to the sizes of objects that can have differing features.  From these first two notions, we could say with confidence that there would be no upper limit to the number of configurations of features that would respectively define all the objects.    So every object in this nonce universe *could be* unique, although this would not necessarily be the case.  Whether or how this little thought experiment might apply to the real world, I leave to better thinkers.   :-)

No, no, no and no. Even if the universe is infinite (in size and in age). Answering “No, because the universe is not infinite” is dishonestly and cowardly eluding the question. I can understand people to be confused about infinities, and ask this very same question over and over again. After all, it’s not an easy concept to grasp, and on the other hand, there is no such thing as a a stupid question. What I can’t believe is that some would have the nerve to answer yes. Regardless of how many PhD’s they have. Despite that, for that matter. The number of things (galaxies, stars, planets, people, yourselves, etc.) in an infinite universe is infinite as in first degree infinity, while the number of possible things (galaxies, stars, planets, people, yourselves, etc.) is infinite of the second order infinity. Look up cardinality of infinities if you like math. Bottom line: the number of possible things ([math]\aleph_1[/math]) minus the number of things ([math]\aleph_0[/math]) is infinite, therefore, the probability of finding two identical things is 1 divided by infinity = 0. A zero probability means an impossibility.

Assume that there are infinitely many planets in the universe that are, say, within 10% of the mass of the earth, and likewise for the other planets in our solar system. There are infinitely many combinations of masses and orbits. So there is no reason to believe that any solar system like ours exists anywhere else. Even less so when you consider the masses and orbits of the moons and rings around these planets. And far less so when you add in all of the comets and asteroids. Considering just the earth itself, there are infinitely many ways that the chemical elements and compounds could be distributed in an earth-sized planet, that water could be distributed, or that heat could be distributed. Even for a single element, say carbon, there are infinitely many ways its 15 known isotopes could be distributed. So it is unlikely that any planet anywhere matches earth in the size and shapes of its continents, in its tectonic movements, or in its internal structure. There is absolutely zero chance that any other planet could have evolved humans.

In my opinion is very unlikely to have copies of ourselves in the universe.  Here is my funny theory:  To have a person identical to you then he must live in identical (100% similar) planet. But to have 100% identical planet like earth, then it must appeared and exist in same conditions: identical solar system with same age, same amount of molecules etc. To have a 100% copy of solar system we also need same galaxy so temperature, speeds etc are the same. and so on .. In the end, to have a copy just like you, there must exist another universe just like the one we live on. So..congrats, you are unique in the universe!

I think so. If you consider a volume of space (let’s say a “cubic parsec”) - there are a finite number of particles within that volume…there are a finite number of positions and momentums they can have. If there are an infinite number of cubic parsecs, then it’s not possible for them all to be different…hence, it seems like there would have to be exact duplicates of them. That said, it could be possible that our cubic parsec is unique within all of the universe - but that just doesn’t seem reasonable. So yes, in my opinion, if the universe is infinite, then there are an infinite numbers of you and I - and probably in enormous numbers of close variations - and at different stages of our lives. One thing is clear though - those duplicates will be far, far from the visible universe - beyond anything we can ever detect or interact with…so in a sense it doesn’t matter that they exist. Beyond being a bit of a brain twister - they have no possible effect for us.

What you are refering to is the Multiverse Theory. It’s just a Theory but let’s say there are infinite universes then there should be infinite numbers of yourself as weird as it sounds. Why? Because infinity is a weird number. If you had let's say 100 universes it would be rather unlikeley but with infinite universes everything is probable and everything will happen. Even universes where Adolf Hitler get’s killed and Clinton doesn’t decide to get a BJ from his secretary. But that’s just speculation ;-)

Essentially, yeah. Only “if” though. The universe MAY be infinite, or it may not, we currently have absolutely no way of knowing which (a finite universe is considered most likely, but all attempts at measuring the intrinsic curvature of spacetime have failed to detect any, space is very flat). There MIGHT be a multiverse, or there might not, we currently have absolutely no way of knowing (nor do we even have any idea of how we COULD detect them, unlike the curvature of spacetime as mentioned above).

I think there's two point of view we're having here.  When we think of infinite of things, we literally think of infinity of combination from low entropy to high entropy.   That's one view, the other view, a bit more realistic is this, What about chance of building block? It seem there's vast of things that destroy each other and the gravity is strong to disallow for a things to build in unique ways.  Chance for like a perfect balance with no disturbance may well give chance to build small things little by little all by itself into a unique form. Earth is one example, that we exist due to questionable factors that we half know and don't know what made us.    So, I don't think we can create a conclusion that "If the universe was infinite then does it mean that there are infinite replicas of everything and even ourselves?"  All answers are valid, it's a yes, it's a no, it's a maybe, and it's a we don't know.

I was always taught that the proper term was “near infinite”. In either case, yes, there are a near infinite number of copies of yourself and they are splitting off (decohereing) at a much faster rate than you can imagine. Read the Cher Experiment portion of CHANGING_WORLDS_LIKE_TV_CHANNELS_Experimental_Proof_of_Parallel_Universes_in_the_60th_Year_of_The_Everett_Wheeler_Hypothesis_Contains to see not only the physical experiment that proves this, but just how fast it can happen, seamlessly and without normal detection.

An infinite number of things does not mean that everything possible is represented.  The universe might have an infinite number of hydrogen atoms, but only one copy of you, and that would still be an infinite universe. You may be interested in the discussion found here:What presuppositions are made in the statement: "In an infinity of universes, there is no fiction"?

Infinite? Unlikely. But, a googolplex or even, a Graham number of you? Perhaps. It’s all in the crazy world of Quantum and the so-called, Copenhagen Interpretation. The Double Slit experiment seems to prove that the outcome of an event is not set until it is observed (wave collapse) and that all possible outcomes exist, somewhere, somehow. That is the multiple world theory, also known as the multiverse. The word has become popular and often misunderstood. We think of it as beans in a jar; a nearly infinite number of co-existing universe. But that can’t be because, if it was, we must ask: in what is the container contained, and so on. It doesn’t make sense. No, the “multiverse” theory must be understood as simply another dimension and you can’t “travel” from one to the other. If you are interested, here are the definitions of the googolplex and Graham number: Googolplex - Wikipedia Graham's number - Wikipedia

Yes, in theory* since there are only a finite number of atomic structures even on the complex level, in an infinite universe these specific structures would have to repeat.  Meaning if there was a 0.1x10^-50chance that your specific atomic structure exists in the universe, multiply by infinity and you'll see replicas throughout the universe.  *this is all statistical speculation and theory.

The notion of eternal recurrence is something that comes up from Friedrich Nietzsche's work. It's about there being an infinite replicas of everything, even ourselves, given a finite universe and infinite time. The observable universe is not infinite, and it has finite mass. It's infinite in the sense that expansion will continue forever and will not be contained in a finite volume. It means the universe does not meet the (philosophical) conditions for eternal recurrence, so there are no infinite replicas of everything.

No, not at all. That is just a naive misunderstanding of infinity. You're starting from the wrong end. Infinite isn't made out of the few things you happen to be aware of. Rather, those things are a very, very small subset of what exists. Infinity is a way of having an endless amount of unique stuff.

I hold a different view in this. As I'm more intrigued by the multiverse theory, you will have one copy of yourself in every parallel universe in the multiverse system. But events caused by you or affecting you in one universe may not affect your timeline in this universe. For example, you may live to a 100 years in another universe, or may be dead in a different one, and still be alive in our universe. Peace!

Only if there was infinite matter in the universe to make the copies of everything. From what we currently see, that amount of matter is finite.  The geometry of the universe seems to be tending toward it being unbounded (aka infinite). So this leads to the conclusion that the universe will eventually freeze - the so called heat death.

Where did you get that idea? I can’t see how the first part follows from the second part. I think you need to learn more logic, in particular higher topos theory http://people.math.harvard.edu/~lurie/papers/highertopoi.pdf.

Yes there may be a similar copy of humans but not exact copies of you .for eg there are infinite number of similar stars in the universe but have some unique or some (not exact) properties .According to different regions and unpredictable conditions in every part of the universe we cannot say for sure everything will be same and they may even differ atleast in one way.
It doesn't mean anything. It makes about as much sense as saying an apple is finite. In what way? The lack of specifics/context is why they're both meaningless.
Not necessarily. /something/ has to repeat, but /everything/ doesn't have to repeat. It might. But if the universe is infinite and non-homogenous, there can be unique things.
Not at all. If you were a number, say 3, you would be unique in an infinite universe where all other numbers (an infinity of them) are even.

Not replicas, which doesn’t exist anywhere, there are always some microscopic differences in every formation. It might help to bear in mind the following equation: X = Y X means the infinity of sameness Y means the infinity of variety
Infinity simply means something undefined. It does not necessarily mean something very large. So, I don't think there is any such association that you are trying to make.

Not necessarily.  What would be the mechanism that would create (or require) replicas of parts of the universe in other parts of the universe? What's more mind blowing is an infinite universe in which every single point is unique.
The universe is not infinite, but if it were than b y the very nature of infinity than there would be.
But of course not. You are unique. After this one is used up there ain't no more of yous.
If the universe had an origin how can it be infinite since it had to expand thus had a finite size?
Max Tegmark makes a compelling argument The Case for Parallel Universes
